column1: Will the value of the FAO Cereals Price Index for October 2022 be higher than it was for September 2022?
column6: ['Business', 'Society', 'Security and Conflict']
Russia news + closing tonight
Future contracts for grains are being revised after Russian suspension of their participation in the grains deal.
Adjusting per Russia pulling out of Black Sea Deal

Markets are expecting a huge increase in cereals prices first thing tomorrow morning in response to Russia's withdrawal from the Black Sea grain deal. Also tracking this: https://www.ers.usda.gov/topics/crops/wheat/market-outlook/
Tying it more to crowd forecast with a little bit of conservatism
Russian exit of Black Sea grain deal likely to exacerbate short term movement of prices within FAO Cereal Price Index

I was wondering how fast the CPI could respond to the news of yesterday - Russia canceling its role in the Black Sea deal for getting Ukraine's grain exported. I found this: https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/russia-suspends-participation-deal-ukraine-grain-exports-tass-2022-10-29/ . It says grain prices are expected to "leap" on Monday 10/31. https://www.reuters.com/markets/commodities/grain-market-braces-price-leap-black-sea-corridor-halted-2022-10-30/ I am increasing my probability.

Updating my forecast, to account for the news now that Russia will be ending a deal with Ukraine to ease out the food crisis. This might close the month with a higher value of cereals than anticipated.
Russia has suspended grain deals with the UN.
With respect to the historical data available--and the gains seen over the past year--I have adjusted my forecast accordingly. Data: https://www.fao.org/worldfoodsituation/foodpricesindex/en/
Since Russia suspended the grain deal for Ukrainian grain exports, prices are more likely to increase going forward.

Russiaâ€™s announcement today that it will halt compliance with the UN brokered grain export deal will have immediate impacts. https://www.nytimes.com/live/2022/10/29/world/russia-ukraine-war-news?smid=nytcore-ios-share&referringSource=articleShare
https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/russia-suspends-participation-deal-ukraine-grain-exports-tass-2022-10-29/
suspended grain deal with russia +winter
Russia suspends its collaboration in the grains deals with Ukraine. This can push the prices upwards further than expected.
Some burning news for all those considering this question and monitoring the ICG index. Russia suspends its participation in the grain export deal.

I've updated my forecast in the condition that it looks a little more possible that the CPI does fall. The prices have been falling over the last few months, but the global stocks are also reduced and other global conditions affecting the supply chain.
Thanks to @slapthepancake for great analysis.
Following @slapthepancake (hope that I will have some time to verify his calculations independently tomorrow).
Winter is coming!

Been reluctant to post this in depth, but most of the information to answer this already exists. The FAO index is a weighted average of wheat (43%), maize (39%), rice (11%), barley (7%), and sorghum (small, I ignore) price quotations. As explained here (https://www.fao.org/3/ca9509en/ca9509en.pdf#page=79), wheat, maize, and barley are sourced from IGC quotations, with rice and sorghum sourced elsewhere.
moving in direction of team. https://www.twn.my/title2/unsd/2022/unsd221003.htm food prices still falling, but question is for cereal subindex, not food prices overall.

I see wheat prices have gone down marginally in recent days, so I will marginally update my prediction downwardly, but not by much because I am still confident in the general trends that led to my original prediction
Still a not, but more cautious.

A stronger dollar will continue to raise prices. There is also lots of discussion about food insecurity in many parts of the globe. Although the actual conditions and locations are probably no more than they were last month. The "noise" could raise fears and anxiety causing a higher demand and reducing supply even in places where there is enough food.
no new data

I think that there is still a reasonable chance the value goes down, but given the circumstances, it will likely go up. From August to September, there was a slight rise after a 5 month decline in prices. September to October has had a historically higher increase in the value, which I think will carry over. With lowering production and slightly increasing wheat prices, I believe the FAO Cereals price index will be higher for October 2022 than September 2022.
You are quoting a Reuters article from Nov 2021: https://www.reuters.com/business/world-food-prices-hit-new-10-year-high-october-fao-2021-11-04/
Australia accounts for 11% of global wheat exports: https://www.internationalaffairs.org.au/australianoutlook/prospects-australian-wheat-exports-amid-ukraine-russia-conflict/
GIven the impacts on the continuing war in Russia
Recently released data shows that the FAO Cereals Price Index rose 1.5% between August and September of 2022. I updated my prediction to reflect this information.
Thanks for sharing @mtngeogeek You've convinced me to increase my forecast.

https://www.asian-agribiz.com/2022/10/12/fao-reduces-global-cereal-production-outlook/ Production outlook is reduced as announced this week. If production is forecast to be lower, will price rise? Also while rest of food index dropped last month, cereal rose: "The FAO Cereal Price Index, by contrast, rose 1.5 percent from August. International wheat prices rebounded by 2.2 percent, linked to concerns regarding dry crop conditions in Argentina and the United States of America, a fast pace of exports from the European Union amid high internal demand and heightened uncertainty about the Black Sea Grain Initiativeâ€™s continuation beyond November. World maize prices were mostly stable, as a strong United States dollar countered pressure from a tighter supply outlook linked to downgraded production prospects in the United States of America and the European Union. The FAO All-Rice Price Index rose by 2.2 percent, largely in response to export policy changes in India." https://www.kaieteurnewsonline.com/2022/10/10/fao-food-price-index-drops-for-the-sixth-consecutive-month/
delivery issues in US, esp for cereals, Slaughtering animals for meat to avoid feeding costs

Currently, the price of the FAO cereal index has been decreasing five months in a row. This is due to the war in Ukraine throwing a wrench into the calculus of the global economy. Because there are no signs that grain production will increase, the price the cereal will most likely get steeper for the month of October.

According to the 14th October release of USDA's Wheat Outlook monthly report, the uS will have the smallest ending stocks of wheat since 2007/08. As wheat is a major constituent of the Cereal Price Index and the US is a major player in global wheat market, this would likely put upward pressure on prices. Secondly, the recent escalation in Ukraine with Russia targeting critical infrastructure will further put at risk global wheat supplies. Lastly, decrease in area under cultivation and lower yields in Europe will further constrain already tight cereal markets. The confluence of all these factors makes an upward revision to the previous forecast warranted.

According to the FAO: "The FAO Cereal Price Index averaged 147.8 points in September, up 2.2 points (1.5 percent) from August and 14.9 points (11.2 percent) above its September 2021 value." I looked at other forecasters' rationale and found sginodia's one very convincing. They looked at the EU's area under cereal production which has dropped below the five-year average and production is therefore expected to decrease significantly. EU Cereal yields have already fell by almost 7% in Sept 2022 compared to 2021 due to the drought this summer.

In addition to the previous explanation, the European Commission also reported on 10/6 that despite EU efforts to ramp up cereal production by relaxing environmental rules, the area under cereal production has dropped below the five-year average and production is expected to decrease significantly. Additionally, EU cereal yields, the amount harvested per hectare, fell by almost 7% in Sept 2022 compared to 2021 and 3% compared to the five-year average. This has been attributed to the summer drought in many parts of the continent that impacted crop yield. This further strengthens my prediction that the Cereal Price Index will be higher in Oct than Sept.

Based on the recently released September Cereal Index, the FAO Cereal Price Index rose 1.5 percent from August although overall food prices index fell. The rebound is due to high internal demand and continued supply concerns amid uncertainty about the Black Sea Grain and dry conditions in Argentina and US that are likely to remain through October.

Updating my forecast by 10pp, based on the recently released Sept prices, which show an uptake in cereal price index relative to August. This is in-keeping with the decline in cereal production announced in Sept. With no changes in cereal production, I expect the trend of increasing price index to hold for October as well.
Reduced the probability slightly on 18th Oct, given the recent news that food price indices are continuing to see a download trend in general.
I have just seen that wheat prices have gone down slightly in the past week, leaving me to slightly downwardly adjust my prediction

In September we saw the FAO Price Index rise from what it was in August. Because there has not been any drastic changes in the market for cereal and the price of grain seams consistent, there is no reason that the price index will not continue to rise for the current month. While the price may not rise significantly, it will get nevertheless get higher for the foreseeable future.

Ukraine Oct grain exports almost return to pre-war levels - ministry - Reuters, Oct 17, https://www.reuters.com/markets/europe/ukraine-oct-grain-exports-almost-return-pre-war-levels-ministry-2022-10-17/
The war in Ukraine and inflation should push cereals prices higher. The war affects expected supply while inflation makes cereals a more attractive source of relatively cheaper calories.
Price of cereals still rising

March 2022 saw the highest jump on the CPI, due to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, and has since slowly stabilized to pre-March levels. However, the recent threats of Russia towards Ukraine, including the annexation of four provinces this week, may point to heightened conflict during the rest of October and disruption of the supply chains of cereals, or further sanctions against the aggresor.
Trend of lowering prices has eased in recent months. Returning to base case of trend for cereal price index to increase in October relative to September.
â€” Ripresa dei trasporti di grano dallâ€™Ucraina favorita dalla ðŸ‡¹ðŸ‡· Turchia
Predicting a higher probability than before because of the recent escalation of conflict in Ukraine that could lead to a surge in cereal prices

Perusing commodity prices for different products included in the FAO cereals index, I see evidence that prices are experiencing a model but perceivable uptick on a monthly basis, suggesting the index will be higher than month than last
3 factors that would make prices in October higher than in September:

The average increase from sept to oct over the last 32 years has been 0.91 and the median increase over the same period is 0.7. In 23 of the 32 years there has been an increase of cereal prices from sept to oct which equates to approx 70%.
There seems to be a trend of upward prices.

Information from sources and historical trends grounds this forecast: the FAO Cereal Price Index increased 1.5% to 147.80 Index Points in September from 145.60 Index Points in August of 2022, mainly due to a 2.2% surge in international wheat prices, underpinned by heightened uncertainty about the Black Sea Grain Initiative's continuation beyond November and the potential impact on Ukraine's exports. As we draw near the closing, I believe this trend to continue and prices to continue to drop.

From 10/7 article- new Food price index fell, but cereals rose. "FAO's cereal price index rose 1.5% month-on-month in September, with wheat prices climbing 2.2% because of concerns over dry crop conditions in Argentina and the United States, strong EU exports and heightened uncertainty over access to Ukrainian Black Sea ports beyond November."

Most of the prices stagnated or increased. However, the prices of vegetable oil went down due to normal harvest times in September. Although the price went down fast, the price drop slowed significantly. I see the supply as going down and demand will continue to increase.

Repeating my forecast."The FAO Cereal Price Index averaged 147.8 points in September, up 2.2 points (1.5 percent) from August"I think the cereals price index is slightly more likely than not to end up higher in Oct than in Sept, but it could easily also bounce down a little bit. But given current production, supply, demand and political circumstances, I think it's a bit more likely to go up than to go down from Sept to Oct.

For each month in the June-Sept period, the price of each of the five commodity groups that make up the overall food price index decreased on every occasion--except for cereals in September. That's 19 out of 20 price movements in the negative direction.

I am changing my projection significantly given the September FAO Cereals Price Index numbers. It changes the trend analysis from consistently falling (quantitative), is in line with prior Septembers-to-Octobers (historical), and aligns to recent trends in supply chain difficulties, particularly given the war in Ukraine (qualitative). Altogether, these factors make me now believe there is a more-likely-than-not chance that October FAO Cereal price is higher than September.

I'm raising my forecast by 1% because of recent data. The FAO Cereal Price Index rose 1.5 percent from August and international wheat prices rebounded by 2.2% (linked to concerns regarding dry crop conditions in Argentina and the United States of America, a fast pace of exports from the European Union amid high internal demand and heightened uncertainty about the Black Sea Grain Initiativeâ€™s continuation beyond November). Additionally, the FAO communicated expected declines in wheat exports from Argentina, India and especially Ukraine from their previous season's levels.
The September prices went higher than August, with reports of possible shortage in supply.
We are still in the beginning of October, but, to my untrained eye at least, the US future prices for corn look mostly flat, while the prices for wheat and rice seem to be trending lower:

While the FAO Food Price index has dropped the last 6 months, cereal prices rose 1.5% in September. ( https://www.fao.org/newsroom/detail/fao-food-price-index-drops-for-the-sixth-consecutive-month/en )

Misread the question and got my earlier forecast the wrong way round. The price index usually drifts upwards towards the end of the year if nothing exciting happens in the world. I think all the global excitement happened in Q1.
I have said in the past that, at least when it comes to food price stuff, @slapthepancake is a force to be taken seriously...

The food index went down overall from Aug to Sept but the cereal index individually went up https://www.fao.org/worldfoodsituation/foodpricesindex/en/ Pakistan's rice production is affected by floodings, projected to persist for 6 months https://news.un.org/en/story/2022/09/1127051
I didn't find any previews of the data that is supposed to come on 10/7 showing September.
I think the index will increase based on the cost of transportation increasing.
As the Sept 2022 data came in and with it I see the variance across the year and the 4-month moving average makes me regress on my optimistic forecast and go closer to a smaller probability.
I dono't have enough information, I'm adjusting based on the crowd forecast.
With the news of Morocco's increase in cereal production, it seems less likely that the value will be higher than Sept 22. Slightly reducing.

After reading comments on historical trends, it doesn't seem that there is such a big shift between September and October. However, September numbers will be released this Friday and will require that I update.
I think the observation from @slapthepancake about the base rate of MoM Sep->Oct changes is fairly persuasive
Smart money seems to have this higher than I do but I have no persuasive evidence either way
ammonium@ferryman

There doesnâ€™t appear to be a clear seasonal shift in previous years between September and October - my eyeballing of the monthly figures gives a uniform split of September being higher or lower than October for the cereals index. The last 5 months have seen the index fall.
I increased my prediction slightly after looking at the historical nominal data for the Cereals Price Index.
Revising upward given historical trend of index increasing towards the end of year
Next FAO report comes out on 10/2, so will update tomorrow
Putin has not escalated militarily as previously perceived, while he is giving assurances of the free flow of cereals.
Reduced marginally based on some reports indicating that other countries are likely to increase cereal production (e.g., Morocoo)
Global Ag production in 2022 will be below 2021. A 3rd La Nina year portends challenging climate conditions (drought) for 2023 crops.
It looks like in the past few years, prices have tended upwards starting in September, so perhaps this trend will repeat itself.
I read the question in inverse by mistake, hence making an edit. The trend of the past few months has been falling, plus the recent grain should further push the prices down.
Considering discussion on falling prices for specific index subcomponents
Even with record harvests in Russia, Ukraine's exports are down 46% and Russia's down 24%. This will push up grain costs as normal harvest restocks are slowed in North Africa and South West Asia.
Updating with fresh data, September data thus far puts the index back at roughly its July level after a dip in August. Wheat and rice trending up, corn mostly flat this month.
Gas prices fell globally this week, now below $4 in U.S. first time since war started.
For the last 12 years, food prices have been higher for October over September.
The FAO Cereals Price Index is constructed from the prices for 5 different types of crops. It is affected by both demand and supply side conditions.
Prices increase in the second half of the year. With a greater frequency of floods and droughts than previous years (such as in Pakistan) inducing crop failure, I am expecting the index to go up.
I marginally updated this number to include a higher chance of this happening studying past trends, current inflation rates

Looking at the past, FAO cereals and other food indexes tread higher in the months of September, October and November due to the seasonal adjustment and cyclical cycles of Winter. With the war on Ukraine escalating and relations with Russia deteriorating, the supply of food such as cereals will likely be disrupted.

The FAO price index in August was 145.2, in July 147.3. Prior to August, the index had been above 160 for 4 months, and even prior to that it was lower than 150. I believe it is likely that the index will decrease.

After some thinking I think I am quite convinced by the meta analysis proposed by @ctsats (who is commendable in his drive to have people reflect on their forecasts on this Q!), but I would rate it just slightly above 50% given that I would weigh a Monte Carlo simulation (outside view) slightly less than the inside view. That being said, there are a few aspects to this inside view which strike me as quite counterintuitive, so I'm still hugging that 50% quite tightly.

The FAO cereal price index continue to decline in last five months and with chances of suspension of exports from Black Sea ports being very less, recent UNGA deliberations on food security and call by POTUS, I am inclined to assign just 5 % probability to the index rising in October,2020.

Given the trend from Aug onwards last year, it does seem that the price goes up in the second half of the year, could be linked to the onset of winters. Also, the numbers are fluctuating and with a +-2% SD - So there is a possibility that it may come down to 145. Hence 60:40
I have looked to the actual price indices, given the date proximity of 31 of October, a tight timeline for the event to happen.
Putin escalates in Ukraine and the US winter wheat production forecast is lower than expected.

This should be lower, but with the recent rise in tensions and Russian threats of escalations (see Putinâ€™s remarks today), I would expect it to go higher and for Russia to use food as a strategic weapon when it suffers strategic losses like what happened in the past week.
Russian situation
I changed my prior based on the new recent events that did not consider previously - the better-than-expected crop harvests and Ukraine's resumed exports of grain.
Based on these factors, I would assign a 40% probability of the index being higher in October.
Updating after discussion with group around stabilizing prices.

Looking at historical data and considering the ongoing impact of Russia's invasion of Ukraine, I think the value of the FAO Cereals Price Index will be higher in October 2022 than it was in September 2022; however, I'm sticking my probability at 30% given the uncertainty around the Russia-Ukraine war.
I think the FAO cereal price will stay the same or go lower due to the Ukrainian conflict continuing into the later part of the year.

Though the FAO Cereals Price index has fallen over the past five months, prices typically rise between September to October as agricultural seasons in many parts of the end or start to end, decreasing available supply. Also, as Russia becomes more militarily aggressive in Ukraine, the bread basket of the world, there will likely be consequences on global food supply chains.

Prices fell significantly now for five months in a row, providing a strong â€˜base rateâ€™ for further falling from historic market highs [World Bank]. Yet, given the importance of Ukrainian wheat for global price mechanisms, there are considerable risks due to the ongoing conflict in Ukraine. Simultaneously, global supply is forecast to shrink, leading to an additional risk in price increases while prices typically increase in winter [World Bank].
The trend of the past few months has been falling, plus the recent grain should further push the prices down.

The UN FAO released a statement on 9/2 saying they expect a 1.4% reduction in world cereal production due to lower than anticipated production in Europe, NA etc. Although the Russia-Ukraine deal on exporting grains did release some of the pressure on cereal production and led to a decline in the FAO index over the past 5 months, I think this announcement is likely to hit prices again, causing them to rise such that Sept price is higher than the Aug one.

I chose this rationale because despite food prices historically increasing between the two months; the overall trend has been down. However, a recent press release suggests that production will go down suggesting prices will increase.

Prices have been falling considerably in the last three months due to improved production prospects, higher seasonal availability, and the resumption of exports from the Black Sea ports in Ukraine. However, Putin may pull out of the grain shipment deal in response to the recent wins of Ukraine and Putin's signaling of increasing military mobilization.

The price has been down for three consecutive months and now with the opening of Ukrainian ports, greater volumes would be available for sale. The only factor that could torpedo this forecast would be an intense new offensive wave from Russia towards Ukraine. The decision this week by Putin for a partial mobilization of Russians males to be conscripted may signal to enhanced conflict in the areas around the port.

I wrongly understood how the scoring works and meant to pick this answer the first time. The main reason for this, after analyzing the driving factors, is that the decreasing trend would still continue at least for another 2-3 months.
While there has been a decrease in the index recently, there is a seasonal price increase in October.
There are many factors at play.

I think there will still be momentum for the Cereals Price Index for October 2022 to go down from what it was in September 2022. However, I think it'll go down less significantly than between July and August. Ukraine is making progress in its advances, even though Russia has made comments about a nuclear threat.
Russia's escalation of the war effort will likely put more pressure on the index
The Situation in Ukraine has increased the risk to food supplies.

Dollar is stronger and Putin's speech today makes relationships and agreements seem more tenuous. Next FAO report is out 10/2. New news reports Syria lost 75% of its grain crop. Seems that an adjustment back down is warranted. https://www.reuters.com/markets/commodities/exclusive-climate-change-conflict-decimate-syrias-grain-crop-un-fao-2022-09-20/

Today (September 21, 2022), Putin gave a reckless message on television that the crisis with Ukraine and with NATO could worsen (https://tinyurl.com/38yh82x7). We know that Putin's war sent global food prices and cereals skyrocketing (https://tinyurl.com/2p8b7p3x), and these prices began to fall when the conflict (at least in the media) had lost "intensity ." With Putin's announcement today, I expect there will be months of great tension raising the FAO Cereal Price Index again.
Bringing my forecast down as the 70% starting rate seems too high when trend over the last few months has been downwards (and didn't feel confident enough in my knowledge to be so far from consensus)

- Overall trend in index has been upward since since 2019, and since 1990 cereals price in October > September 70% of the time (knowing this reflects upwards trend as well as seasonal variation) = start with 70% base rate

The FAO cereals price index depends on the prices of wheat, wild rice, corn etc. The current trend of FAO has been declining through this year. There is no evidence of supply disruptions to the market (which could potentially jack up the prices).

Throughout the past decade, ~60% of September to October jumps has brought Cereals Price increase (outside view). On the other hand, Covid and Ukraine are causing the Cereals Price Index to drop, and it has been going down over the past five months (updates).

My rationale is that, over the past ten years, the Cereals Price Index was lower in October than in September only once, in 2012. All other years, the October price was higher than for the month of September.

The Fed has raised the fed funds rate by 2.25 percentage points in less than six months, in order to fight against inflation. I believe in monetary policy as a legitimate and accurate tool to reduce inflation levels.
Putin announced new changes in how he's approaching the war yesterday

Updating because drop was only for 3 consecutive months, not 5 and because of news from Putin to call 300K reservists. Further escalation of war could impact wheat supply, and therefore increase price.
With the war waning down and trade routes opening in Ukraine and the FAO Food Index Price coming down over the year
Russia initiated a partial mobilization of up to 300,000 more Soldiers for the war in Ukraine on Sep. 21.

Given the trend so far, one could asume that it won't, unless something new happens with the agreements in Europe which is unlikely. However, as the winter comes, Rusia might be emboldened in its actions, so it is possible that the agreements could be affected.

I think the value of the FAO Cereals Price Index for October 2022 will be lower than it was for September 2022. A UN News article states that World food (cereals, vegetable oil, dairy, meat and sugar) prices have fallen for a fifth consecutive month. A Barron's article from September 2nd says that the FAO cereals index fell by 1.4 percent, driven by a 5.1 percent drop in international wheat prices. Since shipments of wheat, corn, and sunflower oil from Ukraine have resumed since early August, I believe the FAO Cereals Price Index will continue to fall. However, CNN reports that last Wednesday, Russian President Vladimir Putin Putin threatened to restrict Ukrainian grain exports to European countries. I will keep an eye on the news to see how Russian-Ukraine export conversations change.

The FAO indices for most of the major food groups have been steadily decreasing May-June peak for the last two months. As Ukraine continues to improve in the war, I expect the index for October to be lower than September. Watch this space.

In typical months, the price index between September and October. However, the invasion of Ukraine has resulted in a sharp increase in the price of cereals, and the price has decreased every month (sans one) since then. That's around 1 in 7, or about 14%. I would round up (because I could be wrong! It really depends on what happens in the War with Ukraine) at 20%.

I looked at the FAO data for every year since 1990 and found that in 72% of years, the Cereals Price Index for October was higher than it was in September. I somewhat lowered my prediction, however, given the downward trend in the index over the past several months of 2022.

Ceral prices in 2022 were much higher than 2021. Altough there s been a steep decline from last months, ceral prices usually retakes the upward trend in the second semester as winter approaches the northern hemisfere. Aloghether considering the global inflation and systemic effects, I found unlikely that the graph will keep going down and cut down to OCt 2021 levels. Nevertheless, I want to know what is the reason of the sudden downfall in the prices for the last months.
Correcting a slight clerical error from my yesterday forecast; rationale still applies: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1508949

For the last three years, the FAO Cereals Price Index was always higher in Oct 22 compared to Sep 22. However for this year, given the war in Ukraine, the price index increased significantly in March and has been on the downward curve since, given this, I have kept the probability at around 40%.

In the past, there has been a seasonal increase between September and October. However, cereal prices have been trending down since May. We are working with an unusually high base because of the war in Ukraine and global inflation, so we may not see the seasonal increase that we have seen in previous years.
Working naturally with a relatively high base might counter act
Decided to update - to a 50% because considerations taken might offset each other

As per data, FAO cereals price index has been declining since June 2022. Based on historic data, I think we can reasonably estimate that the prices will go down. However, given the instability in Russia-Ukraine peace agreements, it may not go down considerably.

According to the FAO website, there seems to be a recent reduction in prices even though signs of inflation are still evident. I would assume that the downward pressure on prices would continue as global monetary policy tightens, but monthly variations may still be volatile and unpredictable.

Russia and Ukraine have come to an agreement to allow the transportation of agricultural products through the Black Sea. Initially, the agreement was not respected by Russia, which makes its continued implementation to look shaky. The conflict is extremely likely to continue through at least October and November and therefore the continued implementation of the agreement is in doubt. At least, there will be several episodes in which ships transporting products will have issues crossing the sea. Hence, the price index is unlikely to be below September levels (the agreement was signed in the end of July but as mentioned, its implementation has been partial).

Although there has been a decreasing trend in the price of cereals over the past few months following the war in ukraine, the cereal price index has generally been higher in October than in September probably due to seasonality.

20 Sep 22 Update - The U.S. Agriculture Department on Sept. 12 lowered its nationwide corn-production estimate to 13.9 billion bushels, 3% lower than its August projection, and 8% below 2021â€™s total. Soybean-production estimates this month were down 3% from a record projection in August, and down slightly from a year earlier. Agriculture advisory firm Professional Farmers of America Inc. last month cut its outlook for corn yields by 13% in Nebraska and 22% in South Dakota, compared with last year. There was an expectation and a need for US supplies to make up for the decrease in supplies from Ukraine.

In the past year, FAO indices rose about 29% of months and fell 71% (rough estimations). While I think the trend will probably continue to fall, as we enter this season, prices might rise (as they did from Sep 21 to Oct 21), so I still gave it a 30% chance. External world events should be monitored as well to adjust accordingly based on supply chain impacts.
I tend to move to a yes -

Noting that they are still above historic average due to the Russia conflict. The July 2022 score for Cereals (a major Ukrainian and Russian crop) was 147.3, which is down from a high of 170.1 in March and 173.5 in May in 2022 but still above ~130-140 in the months before the Russian invasion of Ukraine. The drop in July was likely due to the UN-brokered grain deal reached that months, which reopened grain exports in limited quantities. I foresee the situation in October being very similar as September, meaning the scores will be close.

A lot of up and down possibilities. https://www.world-grain.com/articles/17428-fao-improved-wheat-outlook-helps-check-world-food-prices. Turkey wheat price fell 0.75% in the past week. FAO raised its forecast for world wheat production from its last report in July to 777 million tonnes, a negligible drop from 2021, thanks to expected record harvests in the Russian Federation and positive weather conditions in North America. Australia is also expecting its third straight bumper crop. Global rice production is expected to drop by 2.1% from its all-time high reached in 2021. https://www.world-grain.com/articles/17428-fao-improved-wheat-outlook-helps-check-world-food-prices
The trend seems to follow other commodities and other 2022 trends.

FAO Cereals Price Index usually rise slightly in the fall over the last 4 years. Overall prices were substantially higher in the beginning months of 2022 and researchers attribute it to the Russia-Ukraine conflict. Since the summer, FAO prices fell marking a different patter than the previous several years in the summer months. Even though inflation has been high, the downward trend persisted. I think the trend will continue to decrease but at a slower rate.
Given Russia losing the war, some counteractions will probably follow - impacting the prices.

Since 2019, the FAO Food Price Index increased from September to October, even when decreases in the Index preceded the increase. However, we've seen the Food Index and Cereal Index drop for 5 consecutive months, which is uncommon. Therefore, I set my initial that October will have a higher Cereal Index than September.

Since 1990, the Cereal Price index has recorded month-on-month increases 48 percent of the time. However, in Octobers since 1990, it has increased in 72 percent of months. But, prices have been gradually falling from elevated levels that they reached soon after Russia's invasion of Ukraine. This lowers the likelihood of a price increase in October relative to September.

The FAO cereals price index depends on the prices of a few select kinds of cereal. The clearing price is based on supply and demand. While the demand of cereals continues to rise, in part based on the increasing population, the supply seems to be shaky. The three major exporters of wheat for instance (a component of the price index) are Russia, Canada, and the US. In Russia, production has fallen and reports suggest that Russia may also make it harder for Ukraine to export to continue pressure on Western powers. Canada has had record production which might help however, the US has been undergoing some of its own internal strike-related issues. Historically too prices in October have been higher than in September.
Minor adjustment in the no direction.

The FAO Cereals Price Index has decreased by 1.4% since August. This decrease was due in part to a 5.1% decrease [1] in international wheat prices, a factor which may cause the index to continue to decrease in the coming months. Further, the general Food Price Index has been decreasing for the last 5 months. Nevertheless, the FAO released a cereal production forecast on September 2nd that predicts a decline in production, which may lead to increased prices. In 2019, 2020, and 2021, the Price Index increased between September and October. This leads me to estimate that there is a 40% chance the FAO Cereals Price Index will be higher in October than it was in September 2022.

FAO has had six months of decline, is currently (1 SEP) at 147.3, and its long-term average is 138.0. While the war in Ukraine has continued to put pressure on food prices, they are normalizing since the price hike back in March. I believe there is a higher than likely chance that prices will continue to drop towards their normal base rate.

Firstly, a basic outside rate here is % of months with an increase from September to October. 73% of months saw an increase from September to October since 1990. For each year's September and October as % of the annual average, September is 99.2% and October is 100.5%. So its 73% but with a relatively small average change, so individual circumstances can swing a prediction significantly.

CORRECTION: I have been looking at the FAO Food Index instead of the Cereal Index. More or less shares the same rationale as the Food Index but slightly higher on base rate, with 7 of the past 12 values having been higher than the previous month. Downtrend for 5 month so far. Seems like mean reversion after historically high prices. Probably this continues but I could see it going either way.
It will be lower, the world will be more sable and predictable in October than September.

I hesitate to forecast this question, as it's a volatile index and so many things go into it. But I'm going to forecast that the cereals index for Oct 22 will be higher than that for Sept 22. Russia's war on Ukraine spiked prices in March 22, and the peak in prices was March-May 22. Since then, the index has fallen. The fall from July to Aug 22 was only 2.1 points, but it was a fall. I expect that the Sept 22 index value might be slightly lower than that for August, but I could also picture it bouncing slightly upward. I think the "Ukraine bump" has almost ended (and may have already), especially with increasingly good news coming out of Ukraine, but also as markets adjust to the new realities. Suppose that there is some relatively permanent "Ukraine effect" - perhaps a slight increase in the index. I think over the fall and winter, the cereals index will return to the underlying trend, plus whatever "Ukraine effect" remains. The underlying trend was up. Where would it be now - around 145-150? Are the pressures that moved the index up before the war on Ukraine still happening? One pressure last fall seemed to be fertilizer prices, although that could be debated, as fertilizer prices affect future crops, etc. Fertilizer prices are higher now than they were at the same time last year; what will they do this winter? There was an energy crisis in China last winter that drove up LNG prices, on which fertilizer prices depend; the LNG situation in Europe is bad, but will there be another energy crisis in China this winter, too? I think it's likely that LNG will generally be up, and with it, fertilizer prices, and with those, cereals prices. So, this question is a tough call, and I don't think October's cereals index value will be very different from September's prices, but I think October is likely to be a little bit higher than September as the index largely resumes its pre-Ukraine-invasion trend and is starts to be affected by seasonal increases in gas and fertilizer prices.
